A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if necessary. If there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years either born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: William A.M. George

2. Your address: P.R.E.S.T.A.M., B.C.

3. Date: April 8th, 1975

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Richard Hurl, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1909

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, getting dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.). I was 18 years + 6 months.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? We heard that southern Saskatchewan opened up for homesteading so decided to come west.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people.
1. Your full name: William A.M. Hurlbert

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Richard Hurlbert

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1909

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not, or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.), I was 18 years + 6 months

9. What were your reasons for coming West? We heard that southern Saskatchewan opened up for homesteading so decided to come west

10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people, Reading about it
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was alright.

12. Did you travel by yourselves or with a party (family, friends or other group)? With the family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? CPR to Swift Current Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.). None except my Dad and a friend and myself walked from Swift Current to my friends homestead a distance of over 40 miles.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? At this friend's homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Sec. 35, Township 11 Range 10 W. 3rd.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Clinton, B.C.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Lived on small farm, worked building CPR. 1905-6 from Toronto to Sudbury out. Worked on my homestead.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Lived on small farm, worked building & PR. 1905+6 from Toronto to Sudbury ont. Worked on my homestead.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

a few times a year

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Oct. 27, 1915 in Elsie Bealby Burgess

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, place to settle you, the Oakley family, the Hudsons and quite a few others.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.

my father came with me, and my mother and the rest of the family came in July 1909 and they lived in Herbert Park Hill the next spring of 1910

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

At the farm, one night to feed the horses, it was snowing, but wasn't far to barn, going back to house they couldn't find their way and would have got lost but the lantern blew out and it was only then that they could see a dark object which luckily was the house. The wind was terrific and thermometer zero, they never forgot that experience.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Not very often there was no church or school till spring of 1911 I went 6 miles to visit friends mostly walked or horseback.

and quite a few others

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

My father came with me, and my mother and the rest of the family came in July 1909 and they lived in Herbert Park until the next spring of 1910

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

It fell down one night to feed all horses to new, it was so stormy, but wasn't far to barn, going back to house they could not find way and would have got lost but the country blew out and it was only then that they could see a dark object which luckily was the house. The wind was terrific and temperature zero, they never forgot that experience.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Not very often there was no church or school hall spring of 1911 I went to meet to visit friends mostly walked or horseback

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays? In the 1930s.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion or purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

After 1915 mostly clothing and bedding.

About 100 dollars a year. Now about 400 dollars a year.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Vanguard East Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes, No, our intentions were to stay but having reached 75 years in 1965 I decided to retire.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a school trustee for over 20 years for the Turkey Track School District No. 2687. My wife was a member of Homemakers for 17 years, being president for 7 years and secretary for 11 years. I was a charter member of Turkey Track Homemakers Club in 1918. I was a trustee during 1930-1930, Turkey Track.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Tractor in the Turkey Track district is being used in the case of the first rubber truck being used.
